title: AB 1465
content: The people of California enact the following: Section 12801.5 of the Vehicle Code requires proof of authorized presence in the US for driver's license applicants. The department must verify this and can issue a temporary license while verifying status. Appeals can be made for license denials. On January 10 each year, the department must report costs for verifying citizenship of driver's license applicants to request federal reimbursement. Peace officers cannot detain unlicensed drivers solely based on belief, unless driver is under 16. Inability to get license does not exempt from obeying motor vehicle laws. Section effective January 1, 2015 or upon director's declaration. Section 12801.5 of the Vehicle Code, effective January 1, 2015, requires proof of California residency and authorized presence in the US for driver's license applicants, unless specified otherwise. It will become inoperative on July 1, 2016, or upon a final judicial determination of its validity, and will be repealed on January 1, 2017, unless extended by a later statute. The department must post any judicial determinations on its website. The Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) requires proof of California residency and authorized presence in the US for driver's license applicants, with regulations for verification and appeals. A supplemental budget report is submitted annually to detail costs for verifying citizenship or legal residency, for potential federal reimbursement. Section 12801.5 of the Vehicle Code states that a peace officer cannot detain or arrest someone solely for being an unlicensed driver unless they have reason to believe the driver is under 16 years old. The inability to obtain a driver's license does not excuse drivers from obeying motor vehicle laws. This section will be effective from July 1, 2016, and will be suspended if found unconstitutional by a court. Section 12801.5 of the Vehicle Code now requires proof of authorized presence in the US for driver's license applicants. The department will not issue a license without this proof and will establish procedures for verification and appeals. The department must submit an annual report detailing the costs of verifying citizenship for driver's license applicants. Peace officers cannot detain someone solely for being an unlicensed driver unless there is reasonable cause to believe the driver is under 16. Not having a driver's license does not exempt individuals from obeying motor vehicle laws. Section 12801.5 of the Vehicle Code requires proof of California residency and authorized presence in the US for driver's license applicants. The department will not issue a license without satisfactory proof of legal presence. This section will be inoperative on July 1, 2016, and repealed on January 1, 2017, unless extended by a later statute. The department requires proof of California residency and authorized presence in the US for driver's license applicants. Regulations will be adopted for verification, issuance of temporary licenses, and appeal hearings. A budget report on verification costs must be submitted annually. Peace officers cannot detain or arrest solely for being an unlicensed driver unless there is reasonable cause to believe the driver is under 16 years old. The inability to obtain a driver's license does not exempt drivers from obeying motor vehicle laws, including licensing, registration, and financial responsibility. This section will be enforced once a court determines the act adding this section is invalid. The department will update its website with this information.
